coverage.notes: The base image (img_00) has a close-up view but is slightly unclear due to low contrast and glare. Front and back views are present, but left and right profiles are missing. No complete base or interior image.

image_assessments.notes: Close-up of base marking but glare makes it hard to read.
Clear front view with good detail.
Angle suggests a top view but doesn't clearly show the top surface.
Clear back view but no distinct base or side profile visible.

visual_evidence.notes: Glare in the base image affects readability of any marks. No clear view of the actual base shape or top surface. Good front and back views with visible glaze effects.

key_observations: Tall vase with gradient glaze coloration
Substantial color variation at the neck
limitations: Base shape not visible due to angle

estimated_material.label: porcelain
rationale: Translucency of the material suggests porcelain
Glossy surface and fine glaze work typical of porcelain

proportions_notes: Tall and narrow form with slight tapering

color_behavior_notes: Gradient from dark at rim to light on body
Notable pooling and running indicating thick glaze application
wear_notes: Crazing suggests some age but well preserved

layout_notes: Decorative glazing appears in loose, flowing patterns around the shoulder

rationale: Minor chips visible at the neck

marks_report.notes: The mark is obscured by glare but some details are visible. Further imagery with reduced glare could confirm readings.

interpretation_notes: The mark includes a sunburst symbol; possible upside-down letters.

negative_evidence_notes: The base shows a mark with glare; no other images available for clearer view.

hypotheses.notes: The hypotheses are formed based on observable features and partial mark evidence. Marks are not fully legible, adding uncertainty.

supporting_evidence: Gradient glaze and abstract motifs common in European studio ceramics
Porcelain material with crazing indicates studio quality

supporting_anchors.claim: Gradient glaze, common in European studio pottery

contradictions: Lack of specific European stylistic marks or symbols
discriminators: Signature style typical of European studios

highest_value_test.expected_result_if_true: Marks are more legible and reveal a European studio mark.
highest_value_test.expected_result_if_false: No clearer legibility, leaving European attribution uncertain.

Lack of signature or distinctive maker's mark

final_attribution.notes: The available evidence does not strongly support any single attribution. Issues such as glare on the base mark and missing views limit confidence.

why: Gradient glaze and abstract motifs suggest common features in European studio pottery.
Porcelain material with crazing supports studio quality craftsmanship.

Lack of strong marks or symbols typical of a specific European maker.

final.overall_summary: The vase exhibits characteristics such as porcelain material and gradient glaze that align with both European studio pottery and East Asian porcelain clusters. However, due to base mark illegibility and missing views, no specific attribution can be confidently made. Further imagery and evidence are necessary for a more accurate attribution.

Lack of signature or distinctive maker's mark
